awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the Biology Transitions program is providing support to low-income students with demonstrated financial need and academic promise to succeed in STEM disciplines at Lewis University. The project is funding 28 scholarships over 5 years for transfer students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in biological sciences. The program will expose students to a learning model that emphasizes critical thinking and problem solving, while providing support to transfer students as they transition to a 4-year institution from community college. The supports developed to help transfer students overcome barriers to graduation will have a broad impact on an array of disciplines.

Lewis University's Biology Transitions program will increase the number of underrepresented, economically disadvantaged students who complete 4-year degrees and enter the STEM workforce directly or after completing a graduate program, helping to advance scientific knowledge and provide needed, qualified STEM professionals. Biology Transitions will establish a sustainable and replicable model of communication between area community colleges and Lewis University and develop effective programming between them, providing a supportive pathway for underrepresented, economically disadvantaged transfer students to be successful in a 4-year university environment. In addition to scholarships, the program will incorporate intensive mentoring, academic support, and undergraduate research opportunities to ensure that at least 80% of Biology Transitions participants will persist to graduation.  Professional guidance in the internship, graduate, and professional school application processes will advance students toward STEM professions and increase the number of graduating scholars who continue in a STEM field through employment or graduate school.

por.por_cntn:
Lewis University a comprehensive, Catholic university, was awarded an S-STEM grant in 2018 to support a project titled Biology Transitions. The Biology Transitions Program was designed to assist low income, academically talented students by providing financial and academic support as they move from community colleges to Lewis University and through graduation.

Over the course of the award, including a sixth, no-cost extension year, the Biology Transitions program provided financial support for 40 students, exceeding the anticipated goal of 28 students (Objective 1). The program exposed students to scientific inquiry skills that emphasize critical thinking, inquiry-based problem solving, and the development of written and oral scientific communication, collaboration, and research skills for advanced interdisciplinary science arenas (Objective 2). The program's focus on cohort building, faculty and peer mentoring provided students with the social and academic supports needed to become engaged and invested in the biology program and the greater college community (Objective 3). At the center of the structure was a Scientific Inquiry seminar course. Additionally, the Transitions program strengthened and expanded relationships with three regional community colleges (Objective 4), creating new models for meaningful pathways in the future for under-represented students to choose STEM majors and careers.

At the completion of the project, 25 (62.5%) of the program's students have graduated with a STEM degree, and four others graduated from Lewis University after changing to a non-STEM major.  Others continue actively completing degrees at Lewis university and other institutions of study.  If all of these students achieve degree completion, the anticipated outcome is that 80% of funded program participants will hold a STEM Bachelor's degree, and that 90% of the students will have completed a Bachelor's degree program.

During evaluation of the data, a pattern surfaced about the existence, and potential importance, of informal support structures that are present in the Lewis program; not yet in the foreground of published literature on the variables that promote success in transfer students. One of these was identified repeatedly across all project cohorts, the importance of formal structures that provided opportunities for the students to identify and talk, informally, to other transition students on campus. This is in contrast to most of the published literature that primarily prioritizes financial and academic supports; with social supports being presented as less important, ancillary, or non-existent in the formal program description. In light of more recent research with first generation college students, contextualized by the theoretical frame of the Imposter Syndrome, social supports are being viewed as equally important to the success of students from populations who are underrepresented on college campuses and in STEM majors.

Responses from interviews of the first three cohorts of Transitions students align with qualities of the students most likely to experience themselves as 'imposters' among the traditional student body. Since most of the program's recruits are female, a special focus has been placed on gender and success of transfer into the STEM fields of study. Therefore, the Lewis research team, with the support of the evaluator submitted a paper for publication. The paper was accepted in April of 2024 for upcoming publication in The Journal of College Science Teaching, as of the writing of this report, a formal publication date has not been set. Additional interviews and data were collected during years 5-6 echoed many of the themes that were identified in early cohort interviews, but two themes stood out and were dominant with this group, including STEM career focus & Changes in STEM career focus.

In addition to meeting program recruitment objectives (Objective 1), a number of program activities, such as a Smithsonian DIY museum exhibit (year 2), and two ecology-centered projects during years 3-6, exceeded objectives in ways that are likely to impact the broader community of STEM education scholars and the Lewis University biological and health sciences program. These successful initiatives stemmed from the intensive mentoring structure and program structure that included a Scientific Inquiry course (Objective 2). Most of the graduates remained interested in their STEM career goal (Objective 3). Of those who changed from STEM, most (n=3) selected a study of psychology with others (n=3) choosing graduate school in the sciences. A small number of recruits dropped out of the program or left Lewis University without leaving forwarding information (n=3).Three community colleges partnered with the Transitions program (Objective 4) provided recruitment assistance for 65% of the recruits, mostly at the beginning of the program. Although the last two years of recruits occurred mostly by program reputation and Lewis Admissions efforts (website and advising), the program has increased the Community College awareness of the biology program’s interest and ability to advance the study of their transfer students.


Last Modified: 05/30/2024
Modified by: Marne Bailey
